_meanings:
{@--7@} Attainment
of riches or worldly prosperity, 
regarded as one of the four ends of
human existence, the other three 
being {#Darma, kAma#} and {#mokza#}; with {#arTa#} and
{#kAma, Darma#} forms the well-known triad;
<ab>cf.</ab> <ls>Ku. 5. 38</ls>; {#apyarTakAmO#} 
{#tasyAstAM Darma eva manIziRaH#} <ls>R. 1. 25.</ls>

{@--11@} The actual state, fact of the
matter; as in {#yaTArTa, arTataH#}, 
{#°tattvavid#}.

charge of money,
office of treasurer {#°re na niyoktavyO#} <ls>H. 2.</ls>

a treasurer, one
charged with financial duties,
finance minister.

{3} a new matter or 
circumstance, new affair.

{4} opposite or
antithetical meaning, difference of
meaning.

a figure of speech
in which a general proposition is
adduced to support a particular 
instance, or a particular instance, to
support a general proposition; it is
an inference from particular to
general and {%vice versa%}; {#uktirarTAMtaranyAsaH#}
{#syAt sAmAnyaviSezayoH . (1)#} 
{#hanumAnabDimatarad duzkaraM kiM mahAtmanAM .. (2)#} 
{#guRavadvastusaMsargAdyAti nIcopi gOravaM . puzpamAlAnuzaMgeRa#}
{#sUtraM Sirasi DAryate#} <ls>Kuval.</ls>; <ab>cf.</ab> also  
<ls>K. P. 10</ls> and <ls>S. D. 709.</ls> (Instances of
this figure abound in Sanskrit 
literature, especially in the works of 
Kālidāsa, Māgha and Bhāravi).

one who longs
for or strives to get wealth or gain
any object.

a figure of
speech determined by and 
dependent on the sense, and not on sound
(<ab>opp.</ab> {#SabdAlaMkAra#}).

{1} an inference from 
circumstances, presumption, implication,
one of the five sources of 
knowledge or modes of proof, according
to the Mīmāṃsakas. It is 
‘deduction of a matter from that which
could not else be’; it is 
‘assumption of a thing, not itself 
perceived but necessarily implied by 
another which is seen, heard, or 
proved’; it is an inference used to 
account for an apparent inconsistency;
as in the familiar instance {#pIno devadatto#}
{#divA na BukteM#} the apparent 
inconsistency between ‘fatness’ and ‘not 
eating by day’ is accounted for by the
inference of his ‘eating by night’;
{#pInatvaviSizwasya devadattasya#} 
{#rAtriBojitvarUpArTasya SabdAnuktasyApi ApattiH#}. Strictly
speaking it is no separate mode of
proof; it is only a case of {#anumAna#}
and can be proved by a {#vyatirekavyApti#};
<ab>cf.</ab> <ls>Tarka K. 17</ls> and <ls>S. D. 460.</ls>

a simile
dependent on sense and not on
sound; see under {#upamA#}.

the glow or warmth of wealth;  
{#arTozmaRA virahitaH puruzaH sa eva#} <ls>Bh. 2. 40.</ls>

doing or execution of a business;
{#aByupetArTakftyAH#} <ls>Me. 38.</ls>

due
order or sequence of purpose.

charge or administration of (royal)
affairs; {#maMtrI syAdarTaciMtAyAM#} <ls>S. D.</ls>

{2} the real nature or cause
of any thing.

{2} unjust 
seizure of property or withholding
what is due.

a literary fault or
blemish with regard to the sense, one
of the four {%doshas%} or blemishes of
literary composition, the other three
being {#padadoza, padAMSadoza#}, and {#vAkyadoza#};
for definitions &c. see <ls>K. P. 7.</ls>

{1} intent on
gaining wealth, greedy of wealth,
covetous.

{2} administration of the affairs (of
a state).

derived or 
understood from the sense.

{2} connection (of the
soul) with the objects of sense.

entitled to a share in the division of
property.

distinction or difference of meaning;
{#arTaBedena SabdaBedaH#}.

{2} affirmation, declaratory
assertion, an explanatory remark,
{%exegesis%}; speech or assertion having
a certain object; a sentence. It
usually recommends a {#viDi#} or 
precept by stating the good arising from
its proper observance, and the
evils arising from its omission, and
also by adducing historical 
instances in its support; {#stutirnidA#} 
{#parakftiH purAkalpa ityarTavAdaH#} <ls>Gaut. S.</ls>;
(said by Laugākṣi to be of three 

kinds: --{#guRavAdo viroDe syAdanuvAdo'vaDArite .#}
{#BUtArTavAdastadDAnAdarTavAdastriDA mataH#}; the last
kind includes many varieties.)

{3} one of the six means of finding
out the {%tātparya%} (real aim and 
object) of any work.

comprehending
the sense, one of the six exercises
of the understanding ({#DIguRa#}).

difficulty in the comprehension
of the sense.

a reprehensive 
repetition of something uttered by
another; <ls>S. D. 490.</ls>

one dealing with 
politics, a politician; <ls>Mu. 5.</ls>

accumulation or 
acquisition of wealth, wealth, 
treasure, property.

connection of
the sense with he word or sentence.

{2} bringing any matter to
a conclusion.

understood from the very context (though
not expressed in words), 
inferable from the connection of words.

fulfilment of a desired
object, success.
